Award.AwardTitle: BioMathletic Training: Creating the Next Generation of BioMath Stars at Ohio State University
Award.AbstractNarration:
UBM-Institutional: BioMathletic Training

An interdisciplinary undergraduate research program in mathematical and statistical biology is planned at Ohio State University through a collaborative effort between the Departments of Mathematics, Statistics, and Evolution, Ecology and Organismal Biology. Research opportunities are also available in Computational Neuroscience & Cell Biology. The program will: (1) expose a broad group of students to research problems in the mathematical biosciences; (2) develop curricula to prepare students to pursue advanced study in interdisciplinary fields; and (3) facilitate participation of a cohort of undergraduates in an intensive and integrated research experience involving teams of students and faculty mentors. Beginning students will participate in a seminar course held during every academic quarter that exposes them to the broad area of mathematical biology; while more advanced students will participate in the program as Undergraduate Research Fellows (URFs). The URFs will participate in a mentored research experience during two or three academic years and the summer before their senior year. Each of the co-Principal Investigators associated with the individual research projects have active research programs. Many of the proposed activities will impact a broad group, ranging from students who participate only in the newly-developed interdisciplinary courses to those selected as URFs. The most profound impact of the proposal will be the production of a group of students who are aware of the opportunities available in research in the mathematical and statistical biosciences, who are prepared to enter into graduate study and careers in these areas, and who are motivated to continue working in interdisciplinary fields, in other words- the next generation of BioMath stars. Interested persons may contact the PI Dr. Ian Hamilton: hamilton.598@osu.edu and/or visit http://excelsior.biosci.ohio-state.edu/~eeob/drupal//?q=userpages/85

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project initiated an interdisciplinary undergraduate research program in mathematical, computational, and statistical biology at the Ohio State University through a collaborative effort among the Departments of Mathematics, Statistics, and Evolution, Ecology and Organismal Biology.  This program was organized under the name Research for Undergraduates in Mathematical Biology and its Applications (RUMBA). 

Undergraduate students at the Ohio State University participated in RUMBA in two ways.  First, a cross-disciplinary seminar course was developed and offered in every academic semester.  In this seminar, students are introduced to the tools of mathematical biology, attend seminars on current research in mathematical biology by members of the OSU community, and give group presentations on a mathematical biology topic of the students’ interest. Over 200 undergraduate students participated in the seminar over the lifetime of this project.  The seminar will continue to be offered after completion of this project.

Second, students participated in the program as Undergraduate Research Fellows (URFs). A total of 63 undergraduates majoring in mathematics and biology were funded to conduct immersive, cross-disciplinary research on 29 different mathematical biology research projects.  URFs worked in teams usually of two undergraduate researchers mentored by two or more faculty from the life sciences and mathematics or statistics.  Each team was funded for one to three years, including at least one summer semester. Research projects have included developing models of, for example, transmission of schistosomiasis and foot-and-mouth disease, how cattle herders move, the effects of low oxygen on fish populations in the Great Lakes, methods to identify whether different populations belong to different species, T-cell dynamics, involuntary movement during sleep, and many other modeling projects addressing a wide variety of other biological problems. Mathematics and biology students gained research experience and exposure to methodology from both their major field and the complementary field.  Students learned how to ask biologically-relevant questions, how to formulate biology models, and developed an appreciation for how mathematical models can help in understanding biological processes and in making quantitative biological predictions.  Undergraduate research fellows have presented their results at multiple local, national, and international meetings and have published four papers in peer-reviewed journals to date.
